name: Amazon Luna
description:
Amazon Luna is a cloud gaming platform that allows streaming of video games to supported devices. It leverages Amazon's AWS infrastructure to deliver low-latency gameplay without the need for powerful local hardware.

Luna offers multiple subscription channels, including Ubisoft+ integration, making it a versatile option for gamers seeking a broad library of titles on demand.

name: Anbernic RG351P
description:
The Anbernic RG351P is a handheld retro gaming console that emulates various classic systems. It features a 3.5-inch IPS display and runs on a Linux-based OS tailored for gaming emulation.

Popular among retro enthusiasts, it supports a wide range of game formats and offers portability for classic games on the go.

name: Apple Pippin
description:
Apple Pippin was a multimedia technology console released in the mid-1990s aimed at interactive education and gaming. Despite its ambition, it had limited commercial success and a small library of games.

The console was notable for its collaboration between Apple and Bandai, using a Macintosh-based architecture to bring computing and gaming together in one device.

name: Atari 2600
description:
The Atari 2600 is one of the earliest home video game consoles and popularized cartridge-based gaming. It featured simple graphics and sound but introduced millions to video games.

Its vast library and iconic games like 'Space Invaders' made it a household name and a cornerstone in gaming history.

name: Bandai WonderSwan
description:
The Bandai WonderSwan was a handheld game console released exclusively in Japan. It was known for its compact size, long battery life, and innovative game library.

Though it struggled to compete internationally, the WonderSwan had unique titles and gained a dedicated following in Japan.

name: ColecoVision
description:
The ColecoVision was a home video game console famous for its arcade-quality ports and expansion modules. It offered superior graphics and sound compared to its competitors of the era.

Despite its short market lifespan, the ColecoVision left a lasting impact on gaming, remembered for classics like Donkey Kong.

name: Intellivision
description:
Mattel's Intellivision was a second-generation home video game console known for its advanced graphics and sound over the Atari 2600. It introduced overlays for controllers and expanded gameplay complexity.

While it enjoyed commercial success, Intellivision faced tough competition, but still holds nostalgic value for early gaming fans.

name: Logitech G Cloud
description:
The Logitech G Cloud is a handheld gaming device focused on cloud streaming services like Xbox Cloud Gaming and NVIDIA GeForce NOW. It features a 7-inch touchscreen and Wi-Fi connectivity.

It is targeted at gamers who want portable access to modern AAA games without local hardware limitations.

name: Mattel Intellivision Amico
description:
The Mattel Intellivision Amico is a modern console focused on family-friendly games and simple controls. It revives the Intellivision brand with a lineup of casual and social games.

Though niche, it aims to provide accessible gaming experiences targeting younger and casual players.

name: Microsoft Xbox Series X
description:
The Xbox Series X is Microsoft’s latest flagship console, delivering powerful hardware and 4K gaming capabilities. It emphasizes performance, speed, and backward compatibility.

The console is part of the ninth generation and supports a wide range of games and services, including Xbox Game Pass and cloud streaming.

name: NEC TurboGrafx-16
description:
The TurboGrafx-16, known as the PC Engine in Japan, was a home console with a strong library of games and compact design. It used HuCards for game media and boasted advanced graphics for its time.

While more successful in Japan, it developed a cult following in North America and is remembered for its unique titles and hardware.

name: Nintendo Switch
description:
The Nintendo Switch is a hybrid gaming console that can function as both a home console and a portable handheld device. It revolutionized gaming with its versatile design and popular game library.

With strong first-party titles and innovative features, the Switch remains a best-seller globally and continues to influence console design.

name: Ouya
description:
The Ouya was an Android-based microconsole that aimed to disrupt the gaming market with its affordable price and openness to independent developers.

Despite a successful Kickstarter campaign, it struggled commercially and was discontinued after a brief lifecycle, though it influenced later microconsole designs.

name: Panasonic 3DO
description:
The Panasonic 3DO was an advanced home video game console in the early 1990s that used CD-ROM media. It featured impressive multimedia capabilities but was expensive at launch.

Its high price and competition led to a short market presence, but it paved the way for future CD-based consoles.

name: Philips CD-i
description:
The Philips CD-i was an interactive multimedia CD player and gaming console aimed at the home entertainment market. It featured full-motion video and a variety of multimedia titles.

Although it had innovative features, the CD-i was commercially unsuccessful as a gaming platform and is mostly remembered for its unusual game library.

name: Sega Genesis
description:
The Sega Genesis (Mega Drive) was a 16-bit home video game console famous for its fast gameplay and arcade-style games. It became Sega's best-selling console and a competitor to the SNES.

With a strong library featuring Sonic the Hedgehog and others, the Genesis played a key role in the gaming console wars of the early 1990s.

name: SNK Neo Geo AES
description:
The Neo Geo AES was a home console version of SNK’s arcade system, known for its powerful hardware and arcade-perfect ports. It was a premium system with a high price tag.

Neo Geo AES garnered a cult following due to its exclusive fighting game library and quality hardware.

name: Sony PlayStation 3
description:
The PlayStation 3 was Sony’s third home video game console, featuring the powerful Cell processor and Blu-ray disc support. It marked a significant leap in multimedia capabilities.

With an emphasis on online gaming and digital distribution, the PS3 hosted an extensive library of games and contributed to the rise of the PlayStation Network.

name: Tiger Electronics Game.com
description:
The Tiger Electronics Game.com was a handheld console featuring touchscreen and PDA-like functions. It was one of the first handhelds with internet capabilities.

Despite its ambition, the system was hampered by limited game quality and short battery life, leading to commercial failure.

name: Valve Steam Deck
description:
The Valve Steam Deck is a handheld gaming PC that allows access to the full Steam library. It features a custom AMD APU and a 7-inch touchscreen.

Designed for PC gamers on the go, it runs a Linux-based OS and supports a wide range of PC titles, offering a portable alternative to traditional gaming laptops.
